timely, extinguishing the smoke within the chimney.
From beginning to end, unwavering in single-minded devotion—
better than endlessly coming and going.

Laying down the tangled affairs of the world,
clearly understanding the bright and luminous profound words.
One day, when merit is complete and the spirit is perfected—
selected for Penglai.

**To Daoist Friends in the Capital**
Only because merit was lacking and conduct incomplete,
am I thus compelled to wander east and west.
Since parting two years ago,
the road has turned, the wind and dust stretch for ten thousand miles.

My words are sent to the assembly in Yanshan—
hear my earnest exhortation, do not doubt.
Though external conditions may intrude, forget the mechanism within—
avoid future regrets.

**II**
Though worldly affairs have long wearied me,
how can a Daoist bear to return empty-handed?
Without diligence and hardship, reaching the western passes,
how could one attend Chongyang’s celebration?

I tell the aspirants within our gates—
the ancestral court’s roots are already visible.
The beauty of Zhongnan Mountain is wondrous in all ages—
the elderly may plan to stay long.

**For the Confucian Scholar Wang Zizheng**
The original nature is fundamentally empty and non-dual—
why then are emotions and desires entangled?

One who can suddenly awaken to the Daoist life
sees worldly affairs clearly as mere illusion.
To further penetrate its profound mysteries,
one must brush aside all pride and boasting.
Silently nurturing the spiritual sprout with inner light—
this is the work of non-action and transformation.

**Nineteen Poems from the Clouds of Mount Wu**
*Composed at Qiuyang Abbey*

Nineteen immortal disciples,
following their master through the eight wilds.
Westward to the great city walls of the Huihe,
everywhere beholding fields and mulberries.
One kind of sacred melon, most sweet—
how many in the Red Dust know its taste?
Across the boundless sands of the great chiliocosm,
the crane-drawn chariot returns east again.

**II**
Three years turned in the northern frontier,
ten thousand miles traversed to the western skies.
Light as clouds, the chariot drifts eastward—
all faces brighten with joy.
Virtue towering, merits vast,
practice perfected, one transcends the Three Realms.
When the immortals of the ten directions fulfill their work,
they witness the advent of the Great Peace.

**III**
When the Supreme descended at the Pass,
our lineage received the Dao.
Seven warlords clashed with spears and halberds—
where could compassion arise?
Only when journeying to the Western Heaven to propagate the teaching,
the Great Dharma resounded throughout the world.
Past and present, all alike—
thus the Daoist wind is revealed.

**IV**
A cultivator by the Northern Sea,
a free spirit in the Western Crags.
Parting from his master, he crosses distant passes and fords,
beyond the dust, untouched by worldly filth.
To learn the Dao, one must be resolute—
a heart of true iron, unyielding.
After nine years of practice perfected, he steps upon clouds and mist,
the Three Isles become his home.

**V**
The candle of nature pierces the heavenly eye,
the lamp of mind radiates wisdom’s light.
Serene and luminous, the numinous essence abides in constancy—
nowhere is it not round or square.
Unattached to worldly glory and splendor,
all actions accord with convenience and ease.
When merit is complete, he transforms into clouds and returns,
alone ascending to the Jasper Pool.

**Sent to the Daoist Assembly at Tianchang**

Spring nears its end beyond the mountains,
the scenery of Longyang grows ever fair.
In the eastern garden, plantains bloom—
each follows its allotted life.
Daoist companions, steadfast in resolve,
meet often with bowed heads in reverence.
Naturally serene, harmonious, and peaceful,
beyond the world, there is pure clarity.

**Staff in Hand, Ascending Chanfang Mountain**

A carefree guest of the Three Mountains,
a wanderer at ease through the four seas.
Alone, he arrives everywhere, preserving his true self—
wind and moon are his eternal neighbors.
Seeing through the emptiness of fleeting glory,
who would envy the horses and carriages of the clouds?
A single staff surpasses dragon-drawn chariots—
with steady steps, he climbs the lofty peaks.

**Composed at Xiantian Abbey**

Arriving today at Zhuolu,
Chiyou’s days are long past.
The waters of Banquan flow through winter and summer—
how many springs and autumns have passed since then?
Thus, the victories of mighty armies,
even now remain unsettled.
A life of killing, breeding enmity—
when will this journey end?

**[For a Daoist Companion]**

My companion, steadfast in winter’s sacred land,
the northwest has a breach—
it would cost a thousand merits to repair,
but now is not the time; wait for spring’s warmth to complete it.
Circumstances have obscured the original cause.

I have the joy of forests and springs,
but you lack the heart to mend the breach.

A sacred realm lies secluded in this land,
where kindred spirits meet beyond the world.
When spring returns, all shall be made complete—
a gathering of the Perfected in full.
With merits fulfilled and the Way accomplished,
we shall ascend the clouded heavens hand in hand.

**At Longyang Abbey on the Ninth Day**

White wine eases the heart,
yellow blossoms burst with fragrance.
Such true delight marks the Double Ninth—
the moon of the mind finds its perfect round.
Beyond the mountains, three autumns pass without change,
while hidden railings frame clusters of full bloom.
Two pavilions, each adorned with fresh blossoms,
surpass even the celestial groves of the grotto-heavens.

**Exhortation to the World**

The Dao reveals the wondrous subtlety of clarity and void,
while Buddhism illumines the depths of wisdom.
Confucius’ benevolence and righteousness endure through ages—
the three sages share a single heart.
Yet those who fail to recognize silent enlightenment,
who only divide gates and households,
will one day close their eyes to see the path ahead,
and regret their failure to achieve completion.

**[Divining a Dwelling]**

Divining a dwelling west of the pass,
where ten thousand layered peaks rise,
and the river winds through them,
curving up and down for twenty or thirty li.
Muddy waves surge, mulberry and hemp gleam in the sun,
the people are kind, the land remote—
a fitting plan for one’s final years.
I style myself the Hermitage of Aging,
and send this short verse to mark it:

Ten thousand layered peaks stretch in emerald,
a thousand bends trace the winding path.
The villagers dwell content in soil and sericulture,
flowing waters carry fragrant fallen blossoms.
Here I settle to age in peace,
letting form wither and heart grow withered.
Unmoving, I spend my remaining years—
where else might one seek immortals?

**Inscribed at Tongxian Abbey**

Rows of verdant peaks stand graceful,
the immortal capital’s aura is pure.
The Three Yangs align in the jade turtle’s form,
a single qi shaped by heaven itself.
Amid ten thousand layered clouds and mountains,
lies a grotto-heaven’s secluded garden.
Who could dwell here long in leisure,
finding boundless joy in stillness?

**Urging the Making of a Quilted Robe**

Last night the west wind blew fierce,
this morning autumn’s chill runs deep.
Though the Daoist has subdued the heart,
cold and heat remain hard to endure.
The quilted robe should be made ample,
to drape by day and cover by night.
Even this single garment may not suffice—
where else might one seek refuge?

**At Longmen Creek, Sharing Moon-viewing with Elder Zhai**

The creek’s waters greet the frost with chill,
mountain blossoms bear dew’s freshness.
Good friends together admire the jade toad’s round,
a grand gathering with boundless delight.
I still recall the thousand li of West Lake,
where the pale orb shone clear and whole.
Tonight, three years have passed since then—
it all seems like a dream of wandering immortals.

**For the Lady of Dragon-Tiger**

The merit of the Northern Sea remains unfulfilled,
yet the journey to Red City is complete.
A body in pure stillness forever forgets sorrow—
where might idle cares arise?
At forty, one stands beyond doubt,
understanding all things with clarity.
Rejoicing in heaven’s decree, preserving peace and harmony,
the true principle was never much at all.

**Composed on Clear Water**

The true teaching unfolds in accord with the times,
revealing the precious altar as the moment demands.
The host of Perfected descend to leave traces among men,
yet still they await their place among the ranks of immortals.
Countless beings are transformed and delivered,
each one guided to awakening.
When merit is complete and the Way fulfilled,
they ascend Penglai, spared the three calamities of the kalpa.

**Self-Reflection**

The lands south of Yan are damp and hot,
while beyond the mountains lies a cool, clear sky.
Yin and yang are hard to fathom, topsy-turvy,
old karmic bonds entangle of their own accord.
For two years I’ve endured the journey’s scorching heat,
silent all day, without speech.
In leisure, my merit and practice remain incomplete—
this only steels my resolve.

**Warning Against Ignorance**

A single point of radiant light,
yet three thousand karmic obstacles run deep.
I urge you to search carefully while there’s time—
do not wait for disaster to strike.
Turn yourself wherever you go,
for wisdom’s nature can generate expedient means.
If you grasp these subtle truths,
you hold the ladder to heaven itself.

**Phoenix Perches on the Wutong: Eleven Poems**
*Composed at Autumn Sun Abbey*

The true teaching has spread for a thousand ages,
yet in this fleeting world, how many awaken in their hearts?
Suddenly roused, they seek the path out of samsara—
turning the head, they find the ferry of the true immortals.
With merit complete and the Way fulfilled, they depart for Penglai,
accompanied by Ever-Spring, carefree and without thought.
There are myriad wondrous blossoms beyond number—
who among those not freed from the dust can see them?

**Again**

Worldly affairs stretch endlessly—
when will they ever end?

How could one compare to those who forget worldly schemes,
learning from me to return early to the mountains?
Beneath the peaks, amidst the woods, I often laugh alone—
who among the unenlightened can ever reach this place?
All day in wordless silence, one moves quietly.

Dusk departs, dawn arrives,
yet never a moment of idle vexation.
Cherish the true yang treasure within the body,
no need for elixirs to keep the countenance fair.

**Again**

I know not how to inquire into Chan or meditation,
but wander idly through the world,
only keeping the mind unobscured.
Trampling the void to shatter the six pairs,
beneath the pines on the crags, I sleep fully clothed in one long slumber.

Why boast of quick wit before others?
A single spark of numinous clarity
permits no dust to veil it.
The nature of the Dharma shines resplendent—observe the self at ease,
returning to the root, restoring life, transcending the three realms.

**In Response to the Invitation from Xuande Prefecture**

Beyond the mountains, I have traversed all three yangs.
At Xuande, facing the primal origin—
we must meet before it is too late.
For years, worldly affairs at the master’s side have wearied me,
and I drift alone, blown by the wind.

How many times have I vowed beneath the boundless sky?
Coarse food and rough robes,
cutting off all human ties.
Wealth, honor, and glory hold no allure—
better to perfect cultivation beneath the cliffs.

**Again**

Spring’s light on the crags nears its twilight.

Alas, the spring’s radiance—
no means to detain its fleeting grace.
Spring departs, autumn arrives, the four seasons divide,
each coming and going forging cold and heat.
The reckoning of years deceives, yet none awaken.
Gain and loss, sorrow and joy—
all are but the turns of the wheel of rebirth.
I would leave words of caution and exhortation,
yet the human heart remains unenlightened, with no path to the Unborn.

**Composed at the Temple of Primordial Dao**

Where lies the finest vista beyond the mountains?
In Shanggu’s numinous traces—
since ancient times, the Temple of the Yellow Emperor.
Fountains of pure streams coil and meander,
while emerald cypresses stand in countless ranks.
Today, I arrive in leisurely cloud-and-water wandering.
With unbridled brush, I chant wildly,
laughing freely to open my heart.
Ten thousand scenes cannot assail a mind aligned with the Dao—
the wondrous body of the Perfected True is perfectly luminous and complete.

**Matching the Verse of the Green Void Altar**

Where to fathom the profound subtlety of the Supreme Dao?
Deluded thoughts and perverse reflections—
these are the demons and beasts of the mind.
To cultivate the three fields and nurture flourishing sprouts,
embrace true constancy, true stillness, true imperishability.
The five qi converge at the origin, the true One resounds.
A thousand words, ten thousand phrases—
one must await the dissolution of the six yin.
From ancient times to now, the deluded fail to perceive:
vainly do they transmute the wondrous into festering sores.

**Again**

Turn inward to investigate that single spark of numinous clarity.

**Dispelling the Myriad Demons**

Scatter all the host of demons, drive off the beasts of the western mountains.
Ten thousand trees of jade blossoms weave brocade—
ever-springing, forever claiming rootless imperishability.
Cloud-friends from the four seas come and go in harmony.
Above and below, the primal harmony surges,
gradually the six yang arise.
A single ray of numinous light pierces bone and permeates marrow,
the fragrance of purity transforms the very scent of the womb.

**Expressing My Feelings**

I have nearly traversed the realm entire,
ten years of toil—lest I betray my master’s vow.
Now old, I let go, leaving worldly affairs far behind,
roaming mountains and rivers, following fate’s turn.
I tell my kindred spirits: heed my counsel.
The kalpa’s blades and soldiers—each shall witness them firsthand.
Yet still they cling to craving, to love and attachment.
How can they escape the perils that lie ahead?

**Composed at the Temple of Flourishing Peace in the Era of Great Prosperity**

Ancient traces, a jade palace—worthy of my resolve.
Cypress and pine, verdant and deep,
bear the breath of everlasting spring.
Only when merit is complete shall deliverance be met,
in wordless stillness, one accords with Heaven’s intent.
Fortunate to find this tranquil, serene abode,
throughout the day I wander carefree,
my heart unburdened by entanglements.
Now aged, I withdraw of my own accord—
when will the world’s endless clamor cease?

**Remembering My Master**

My master often spoke of it:
Yanshan was the finest place under heaven.
Sure enough, it was there he was laid to rest.
I record his meaning in these humble verses.

Where in the world is scenery so fine?
Mountains and seas commune in secret,
none compare to the Dao of Yanzhong.
Cloud-friends from the four seas gather and circle,
my master, in silent awakening, knew to return here.
Once entered into the Mystery’s gate, one must awaken early.
Who understands the cultivation of truth?
This matter is not trifling.
Heaven’s intent is clear—it allowed a temple to rise,
Yanshan’s thousand-mile embrace.

**Ten Lyrics to the Tune "Linjiangxian"**
*On the Manifestation of the Primordial Origin*

Since parting from the capital, worldly affairs have dwindled,
not a speck of dust clings to my heart.
Idle songs, idle verses—silently I nurture the spirit.
All that is "with" is but delusion,
all that is "without" is the complete truth.
Embracing nature, a carefree wanderer of clouds and waters,
detached, indifferent, a man of leisure.
Following fate, at peace, free from close and distant ties.
The three yang near their fullness,
the five qi naturally converge at the origin.

**For Madame Yuan**

Madame Yuan dwelt in the desert for ten years,
then left the household, returning to the capital.
I compose these verses to honor her.

Ten years acquainted with the desert’s vastness,
now, in a single dawn, she returns to the capital’s gates.
Each thought stirs sorrow in her soul.
Put aside the tale of Su Wu,
say no more of Han’s Lady Zhaojun.
Past and future—all swept aside.
Fortunate to meet the true master, Ever-Spring.
Your devotion to the Dao grows daily anew.
August Heaven would never betray virtue,
nor would the Earth Spirit fail one so worthy.

**Seated in Stillness at Western Mountain**

**Seated in Stillness at Western Mountain (continued)**

Seated in stillness at Western Mountain brings profound benefit,
rarely does one encounter the affairs of the mundane.
All day, well-fed, I indulge my carefree indolence.
Nurturing a body of purity and quiet,
transforming into the true master within.

For thirty years, I sought in vain through chaos,
now, at last, I recognize the true countenance.
Wild passions extinguished, all dharmas empty.
Originally, there was nothing to be done—
how futile the thousand efforts expended.

**Again**

It was ever a solitary thing,
yet stained by attachments, hard to know.
Deluded clouds disperse, the wind of wisdom blows.
Why seek beyond the self?
Sitting upright is the western heaven.

A thousand words, ten thousand phrases—all in vain,
yet enlightenment comes, and even "one" becomes false.
Advance at the pole’s tip, let no doubt arise.
Let go of all, one by one,
and every kind of bond will fall away.

**Again**

Having penetrated the Quanzhen teaching of purity and stillness,
why labor over scriptures and sutras?
Seek the trace and reason here.
Do not cling to deluded views,
nor refuse to turn back.

How could the true nature ever be extinguished?
Beyond true emptiness, idly searching.
Within it, desireless, recognize true cultivation.
Following conditions, ever still and settled,
responding to things, naturally complete.

**Admonition to the Assembly**

Eyes meet a thousand differences—nothing to grasp,
the mind at leisure, one realm suffices.
The true and constant, undimmed, the valley spirit clear.
All demons vanish from this,
and the single point naturally achieves perfection.

Beyond the world, chanting in purity brings solitary joy,
in the human realm, what do honor and disgrace matter?
I urge you to swiftly awaken and inquire of the path ahead.
To seek the true and real,
do not discuss false cleverness.

**Reflections**

The Provincial Governor Li invited me to Shandong to bury the Three Masters.
The Daoist communities and common folk of Yanjing all refused.
A decade has passed since we parted in Weiyang,
traversing the western frontier to the ends of the earth.
Returning, I dwell in the immortal palace of Yan.
Establishing teachings to clarify the ancestral doctrine,
expounding the Dharma to follow the masters’ footsteps.

Heaven’s will is not easily fathomed,
human sentiments, once exhausted, are hard to plumb.
My heart has always loved simplicity and leisure.
Yet I am made to dwell north of the sea,
not permitted to cross into Shandong.

By chance, I found:
Those who discourse on the wondrous and the profound are easily awakened,
but true purity and true stillness are hard to uphold.
Worldly affairs are unworthy of pursuit.
Among the ten directions, those with clear eyes—
who study me lack discipline.

Having awakened, one must return to simplicity,
throughout the day, let plainness and sincerity abide.
Concealing light, silent, outwardly like a fool.
The mind bright as the radiant moon,
the nature still, aligned with the perfect measure.

What has form and center is easily found,
but formless and placeless are hard to attain.
All day, the shadow alone keeps me company.
Fools seek but do not see,
the enlightened already know.

Diligently investigate this principle to grasp the truth,
a single great path without delusion.
I urge you to swiftly awaken—do not hesitate.
Constantly forgetting sight and sound,
step by step, enter the realm of mystery.

**[Gift to the Daoist Assembly]**
During my summer retreat on Wuhua Mountain,
a Daoist assembly came to see me, and I offered these words:

For years, I wandered the world through hardship,
now, by good fortune, I meet forest and spring.
Hungry, I eat; tired, I sleep.
A few leagues from the city,
lies another small paradise.

Seated above, the mountains and waters all flourish,
in the pond, blue lotuses bloom in full.
In old age, merit and conduct are hard to complete.
Unable to reach the Three Isles,
I first become an immortal of Wuhua.

**[Eight Poems Free of Worldly Thoughts]**

**To the Daoist Assembly of Longyang Abbey Requesting the Dharma of the Unified Mind**

Beyond the three vehicles’ wondrous essence,
the fruit severs birth and extinction.
All things know emptiness—nothing to grasp,
wisdom-nature shines bright, utterly clear.
Within stillness, heaven and earth;
in leisure, sun and moon—
worthy of sharing with a true friend.
Returning to my mountain home,
endless wind and moon await.

A speck of formless true suchness,
limpid and profound,
inner and outer indistinguishable.
To fathom the mystery’s core,
cast off wayward thoughts and folly.
Diligently discuss the subtle,
frequently cultivate the secret,
penetrate the celestial mechanism’s key.
If not now, when will you rest?

Again:
The myriad beings, all from primordial qi,
born of the boundless.
The clamorous multitudes cling to self,
while silent true emptiness eludes them.
Seeking nothing within being,
finding being within nothing—
who discerns this truth?
Only the perfected ones, in their expedience,
sing of the mystery’s essence.

This hidden gate of tradition
requires wisdom,
purity to open the heart’s chamber.
Having seen the original true face,
why covet fleeting splendor?
Dwelling in the human realm,
name inscribed in the immortal register,
not a speck of dust allowed to delude.
The spirit unshaken,
from of old, heaven and earth cannot fathom.

Again:
Winter’s cold, summer’s heat,
spring’s blossoms, autumn’s moon—
year after year, unchanged.
Only the body alters from dawn to dusk,
unaware of life’s hastening end.
Through ten thousand kalpas of confusion,
a single moment of awakening—
best to still the heart and rest.
Not a speck of dust clings,
the original luminous clarity.

Leisurely facing tortoise, crane, and pine peaks,
forest springs and secluded gardens,
freely opening the heart to joy.
When merit is complete and work perfected,
ascending the assembly,
only then does a man’s heroism shine.
This principle is not profound,
the mystery’s mechanism not distant—
yet without awakening, how can it be explained?
Who in the world understands?
In darkness, years pass in vain.

Again:
To the ends of the earth,
roaming freely wherever,
a body at ease.
Knowing worldly affairs as empty as wind past the ear,
yet finding some joy in fellowship.
Jade tripod simmering,
golden furnace boiling,
refining cinnabar elixir.
Consumed, one departs,
the transformed body soaring beyond the void.

Thus the immortal Dao’s subtlety:
shedding the dust of the mortal realm,
one joins the covenant.
Understanding the principle, penetrating reality,
virtue perfected—
why dwell in secluded cliffs and gorges?
The four marks dissolve,
the three corpses flee,
only because human sentiments are shallow.
The teaching of the Perfect Realization,
the great and upright heart—no error.

**Following Another’s Rhyme**

Mingling with the world,
grasping the profound mystery’s intent,
delving into Zhuang and Lie.
Gathering cloud companions to uphold the true teaching,
following the former masters without distinction.
Outwardly serene and kind,
inwardly steadfast—
truly like the foolish and dull.
Gate pure, household quiet,
naturally revealing loftiness.

The boundless realm of Perpetual Spring,
eternally cool and refreshing,
everywhere fit for rest.
Beyond the world, in the purest realm of the pot,
playing amidst white clouds and golden palaces.
Body lodged in the dusty world,
nature reaching beyond the heavens—
nothing can entangle.
The six senses unmoved,
this is non-arising, non-ceasing.

**Mid-Autumn Moon Viewing at Qiyun Abbey, Da’an Mountain**

Da’an’s lofty heights,
wind and dew pure, air crisp—
mid-autumn season.
Cloud friends and rosy companions gather,
together admiring the mountain’s bright moon.
Illuminating a thousand peaks,
brightening ten thousand ravines,
sitting in joyful heart.
Spirit clear, bones cold,
forever transcending the world’s rise and fall.

Gazing upon this night’s splendor,
words and brush labor in vain—
how to describe such wondrous scenes?
Shining upon a thousand gates, all may delight,
yet none compare to Qiyun’s purity.
Before the small courtyard, by the cliff,
beside the Great Cold Ridge,
seeming to touch the heavens.
Sitting in silent contemplation,
this place is fit for dwelling.

**Composed at Tongxian Abbey**

Tongxian’s secluded ground,
deep in the western mountains,
leaning against the cloud-touched traces.
Overlooking peaks upon peaks,
cutting off the red dust’s news.
Strolling amidst misty vines,
quietly chanting to wind and moon—
who recognizes such matters?
Cultivators of truth,
where else could one seek them?

An unbroken stretch of mountains and rivers,
cave heavens and secluded gardens—
a realm of immortals.
Who, entangled in fame and profit, can reach it?
Hard to accompany the pure and idle wanderers.
Sleeping high in jade grottoes,
sitting steady on clear cliffs—
why envy the mansions of kings and lords?
I have come several times,
lingering here many days.

**On Nature**

Spanning past and present,
this luminous, aware nature—
never lacking.
Who recognizes its perfect wholeness?
Chasing appearances, lost in confusion.
Ten thousand actions,
a thousand creations—
all resolved within the heart.
A touch of mystery—
when will you understand?

Not entering the formless mystery’s gate,
floating names hard to relinquish,
greedily gazing at idle flowers and grasses.
Mouths speak of purity, hearts unenlightened,
unaware of the wheel’s return.
Grasping the true mechanism,
startled from the dream of illusion,
freely roaming the three isles.
With a share in long life,
forever transcending the world’s decay.

**Conclusion of the *Baoguang Collection*, Volume Two**

**Ci Lyrics by the Perfected of Pure Harmony, Yin Zhiping**
*Fourteen "Jiangchengzi" Poems, Matching the Rhymes of Scholar Guo of Cangai*

**1.**
Riding chariots, mounted on horses—east and west we roam.
Discussing the mystery’s compass, entering subtleties deep.
The world’s peaks and valleys,
each by lot finds its stair.
Our teaching spreads, heaven and earth protect it—
none fail to rejoice, all take refuge.

**2.**
Who awaits the message within?
Mastering non-action, knowing the uncontrived.
Cloud friends and mist companions,
the heart’s ground must be level and smooth.
Embracing simplicity, preserving the true—daily use shines:
the spirit radiant, the nature luminous.

**Composed at Longyang Abbey on the Winter Solstice**
Six yin phases spent, one yang arises.
Hidden sprouts, light snowflakes fall.
Nine nines of bitter cold,
rivers and seas freeze in layered ice.
The two qi circulate without abiding—
yang’s count fulfilled, the dragon ascends.

Returning to the root, restoring the mandate, the numinous nature brightens.
Passing the heavenly court, entering the formless.
The celestial mechanism’s return,
the moon’s glow ascends and descends.
Seizing heaven and earth’s true transformation,
merit complete, one journeys to Penglai.

**3.**
The Daoist’s livelihood—daily the face opens in joy.
The nature broad, the six spirits at peace.
Concealing traces, veiling light,
no affairs reach the heart.
Nurturing that primal, numinous substance,
seekers of fame and profit cannot compare to leisure.

**4.**
How much joy can a life hold?
Age wears one down, the gate of life and death looms.
The six paths of rebirth,
coming and going in bitter hardship.
Best to recognize our gate’s intimate Way—
severing passions, rising beyond the dusty world.

**5.**
Dharma-light illumines widely, the Dao’s gate flourishes.
Emerging from heaven’s length, entering Longyang.
The precious hall complete,
morning and evening incense burns in the heart.
Cloud friends and mist companions—seek not without,
the heart’s ground steadfast is heaven.

**6.**
South of Yan and north of the River—how sorrowful!
In this desolate wild, enduring frost and wind.
The kalpa’s turning,
when will one reach the immortal land?
Who understands the intent of dwelling in seclusion beyond the mountains?
*[Text missing]*... the small Peng Isle.

**On the Twelfth-Month Snow**
Jade blossoms swirl, pearl dust flies.
Filling the long embankment,
piling at the wicker gate.
Warmth by the window, brightness within—
what need for embroidered curtains?
Night still, clouds withdrawn, the silver mirror full,
watching the snow and moon vie in splendor.

**7.**
The season’s end—a true marvel, rare through ages.
Aiding winter’s might, revealing the year’s abundance.
Moving poets’ souls,
their spirits enter the subtle and profound.
The talented Lady Xie could not exhaust its praise—
leaving it for us, Daoists, to know.

At Xishan’s Tongxian Abbey, the ritual for Chongyang was set.

light snow falling—all grew anxious.
After the eighth day’s proclamation, suddenly the skies cleared,
two days and nights completed.
On the tenth, snow returned—
a thousand mouths as one praised the rare and wondrous omen.

**8.**
Chongyang’s fine festival, the ritual at Western Mountain.
Dusk’s chill, leaves mottled.
Harmonious qi fills the riverlands,
none fail to smile.
Stagnant souls and lonely spirits all receive deliverance,
merit complete, emerging from the dark gate.

**9.**
River clear, valley still—qi at ease.
The heart’s inch wide, preserved whole and calm.
White wine, yellow blossoms,
a grand assembly at the immortals’ altar.
Together we celebrate our gate’s ancestral master’s protection—
the host of perfected rejoice, ten thousand people cheer.

In the Gengyin year, returning from Tongxian’s ritual, the wish unfulfilled.

Since parting at Jade River, leaving Western Mountain,

Letters summon, one must attend the pure altar.
Though delivering the dead and transcending life is good,
the years are late, temples streaked with silver.

**11.**
Cultivating the true not yet complete, accumulating merit hard.

The work of transformation,
all in a moment’s time.
Turning the mysterious mechanism, perfecting utmost virtue—
no desires remain, one joins the immortals’ ranks.

Precelestial’s parting—thoughts sink in silence.

No scorching heat remains, nor do mosquitoes invade.
In pure stillness, dwelling brings lasting peace—

Here, Daoist friends hold firm resolve,
daily seeking, chanting pure tones.
Inquiring the Way, exalting truth,
linking past and present with clarity.
Through nine summers, what can I offer in return?
As I depart, I leave these rough verses.

**Midwinter**
*Tracking Dragon’s Auspicious Traces at the Ancient Immortal Altar*

Mountains embrace waters, winding paths curve.
Jade halls and vermilion gates
tower amid white clouds.
Could this be Penglai’s palace by the misty shore?
A land of true blessing—
where joy may unfold.

**Midwinter Travels**
No bitter cold in winter’s journey.
Daoists gather, hearts rejoice in words.
Having seen the Three Peaks,
after parting, both grow idle.
When shall we laugh again beneath the pines?
Scattering is easy,
but reunion proves hard.

**Winter in the Square Retreat**

Together in winter’s square retreat,
we praise the secluded dwelling,
discussing the primordial beginning.
Conversing past midnight,
all seems to touch the clear and void.
A thousand affairs sought with intent—yet unattained.
Rely on *Xiangwang*,
and grasp the mysterious pearl.

One word settles all—
nature abides in suchness.
Delighting in non-action,
riding the cloud chariot,
we pay homage to the lofty perfected,
our merit complete, ascending to the immortals’ capital.
Swift awakening—all share this portion.
Hear my counsel:
do not cling to folly.

**Composed in Yizhou**

The world’s tangled dreams offer no rest,
even briefly.

**The Ant’s Endless Cycle**

The ant’s endless cycle—
rarely does one smile.
To awaken to the Dao, refine the true,
one must break free from death and life’s gate.
Recognize the primordial beginning as empty of all things—
cast aside delusion,
sever all high aspirations.

In old age, ease and joy suit idleness best.
Lay down the fishing rod,
return the boat to shore.
Wander beyond the world’s dust,
traverse the ancient immortals’ altars.
Wait yet for the Eastern Lord’s message—
cross the Liao River,
gaze upon Mount Lü.

**Another Reflection**

Cultivation reveals deep karmic roots.
Finding a kindred spirit,
the heart at once grows clear.
Through the twelve hours,
external realms cannot intrude.
To preserve life and perfect the true requires no other art—
so easily done,
yet not hard to seek.

**A Timeless Insight**

All at once, the ancient and present are seen through.
Trust in idle chanting,
delight in distant peaks.
From sea’s edge to heaven’s end,
every place is a fine sanctuary.
Carry on the lineage, uphold the teaching—
enjoy heaven’s rank,
earn the world’s reverence.

**Composed at Zhenchang Abbey, Yuci County**

The true and constant responds to things with square and round.
Follow conditions as they come,
fulfill the work in full.
Eyes upright, heart bright—
recognize the power of transformation.
In daily use, be selfless, nurture with integrity;
vast *qi* fills all,
revealing the embryo immortal.

**A Moment of Boundless Joy**

In this hour of celebration, boundless joy arises.
Pierce the profound mystery,
eternal and unbroken.
Illumine the human realm—
how can illusory realms endure?
Then make lasting plans for the old homeland—
observe the Eight Waters,
wander the Three Rivers.

**Moonviewing at Shenxiao Palace, Qinzhou**

Pure light gleams bright in the evening sky.
Perfectly clear,
it suits the secluded mood.
Delight in the moment,
a lofty gathering of cloud-borne friends.
Tonight’s clarity shines down in boundless radiance—
without this evening,
where would peace be found?

The azure sky like water, the moon full and bright.
The pearl of nature stills—
preserve it for long life.
The four seas flow clear,
where is there no fulfillment?
Grateful for the exalted one’s profound virtue,
overseeing all lands,
the teaching flourishes.

**Five *Wumeng Ling* Poems**
*Composed at Longyang Abbey during the Spring Equinox*

Fellow Daoists refine sleep through three winters,
forging the lineage of Chen Tuan.
A new spring passes in an instant—
day and night must be met with blessings.
Blessings, blessings—
let every drop fall to earth.

**Five More *Wumeng Ling* Poems**
*Composed at Longyang Abbey during Spring*

In spring’s sleep at Longyang, I awoke to the true meaning of spring’s light.
The sun already three poles high—
yet startled awake by the spring wind.
Startled awake, startled awake—
all things are but a spring dream.

---

Quietly burning heart-incense in secret,
the three realms and ten directions become clear.
Across the four seas to the ends of the earth,
all are branches and leaves of the Perfect Realization.
Branches and leaves, branches and leaves—
piercing through the bright moon of the clear night.

---

I keep to my secluded window, guarding simplicity,
seeing through spring blossoms and autumn moons.
When the meaning is grasped, I return—
best to rest body and mind.
Rest, rest—
forging a furnace of spring snow.

---

To speak of this toilsome life as a dream,
each one deluded in empty slumber.
Silently awakening the mind’s opening,
attaining true communion in a pure dream.
Pure dream, pure dream—
who would believe the perfected are dreamless?

---

**Two Poems for the Unemotional Scholar**

Each night at the third watch, we questioned one another,
breaking through the falsity of human sentiments.
Each one awakened to the true source—
the heart of Dao flows free.
I hope Qiuyang will turn his intent back,
not indulging in spring’s high sleep.
Soon he will return—
his smile will bloom.

---

Unshunning the distant spring wind,
coming and going, silently conveying true intent.
Which one is my home?
Trusting the ends of the earth.
The original nature, mysterious and unobstructed, without attachment,
brings peace to this body wherever it goes.
All is clear—no east or west—
dwelling on Cloud Peak.

---

**Following Dongchuan’s Daoist Companions**
A guest from Western Mountain awaits.
What is this true intent?
Lo, lo.
Seventy has always been rare—
now I reach sixty.
The floating world is not steadfast—
drunk and carefree.

---

**Reply to Daoist Friends of Xuande Prefecture at Qiuyang Abbey**

Deep thanks for your invitation,
arriving just as spring’s command begins at West Cliff.
A hundred birds clamor in joy—
no delight left unexpressed.
The Daoist assembly fills the valley with harmonious qi,
after the rites, we await heaven’s will.
Karmic affinity merges with emptiness—
east or west, as it may be.

---

Only wishing for a peaceful body and tranquil mind,
who would envy the comings and goings of invitations?
The true teaching fills the ends of the earth,
crossing the Flowing Sands.
The master’s intent is truly compassionate and universal,
meant to awaken all beings.
Cultivate boundless deeds—
the nature will then be round.

---

**Parting from Daoist Friends of West Mountain**

I have wandered to the corners of the earth,
yet none compare to the joy of West Mountain’s heart.
When the mood is spent, I return east—
my temples streaked with silver.
We have both passed the age of sixty,
what assurance is there after parting?
Only wishing each heart may rest—
forever without sorrow.

---

Three elders share the blessing of purity,
spending days roaming the mountains, never enough.
Sitting and lying amidst white clouds,
gazing at green peaks.
After the meal, on the eastern slope’s rocks,
laughter and talk open the heart’s vastness.
Such wondrous scenes banish sorrow—
facing the clear stream.

---

**Parting from Daoist Assembly of Weizhou**

In the tenth month, journeying through Weiluo to teach,
sending off and welcoming carriages and horses.
Harmonious qi fills the mountains and rivers—
the wind of the teaching spreads.

When will we meet again after parting?
Only wishing each heart may awaken.
Accumulate merit to three thousand—
transforming demons into spirits.

---

The ninety-ninth day, severe cold with ice congealed,
behind the mountains, the north wind howls bitterly.
Heading west—what is your intent?
Lo, lo.
Daoist friends, a single word of farewell—
take care not to stir the heart.
Keep your will steady and harmonious—
the Dao is without demons.

---

Wherever there are Daoists and companions,
do not let human sentiments grow thick.
In all things, remain ordinary—
fewer calamities will come.
After parting, you should head west,
patiently receiving and attending to all who come.
One day, we must meet again—
looking toward Zhongnan.

---

**Composed at Huairen County**

I love Huairen in winter’s moon,
warm kang, bright window—fit for rest.
Heaven’s will allows no idleness—
crossing South Mountain.
East or west, not by my wish,
I have nearly traversed the corners of the earth.
The fruit of Dao is still unripened—
I set forth once more.

---

**Retiring in Old Age to Qin Prefecture, Then Returning to the Great Longchun Abbey in Yanjing at the Imperial Summons**

In the tenth month, the lesser spring’s command,
all things return to their roots, settling in stillness.
Only I wander between water and clouds—
crossing East Mountain.
Pointing straight to ancient Yanjing, without fixed abode,
though old, how dare I defy heaven’s decree?
Turning my head to gaze at Zhongnan—
I will come to visit again.

---

**Matching Rhymes to Part from Prefect Du of Qinzhou**

Unenlightened, it is hard to align with heaven’s command,
who understands stillness born from movement?
The Dao lies between being and non-being—
separated by a thousand mountains.
Departure and stay, free from doubt, the heart settled,
following fate with carefree ease.
All day, not lost to the south—
what more is there to seek?

---

**Seventeen *Jianzi Mulan Hua* Poems**
*Composed at Qiuyang Abbey to Exhort the World*

Piling gold, amassing jade,
day after day, greed and stinginess never satisfied.
What more is sought when enough is had?
Only awaiting the barren grave on the wild moor.
There is a path to turn back—
why do fools remain deluded, unenlightened?
If they awaken and turn back,
they will spare themselves endless sorrow ahead.

---

This toilsome life wastes lives—
who understands that clothing and food are all predestined?
Indulging in desire, greed, and ignorance,
accumulating karma like mountains, yet unaware.
One day, when retribution comes,
even those with iron gall and bronze hearts will regret.
Suffering without end—
how they will hate not having heard of early cultivation!

---

Stubborn folly unceasing,
fortune and misfortune still follow the body like a shadow.
Calamities and heavenly disasters—
all arise from the hearts of men.
If this principle is understood,
all things should be seen as oneself.
Once the celestial truth is perceived,
good and evil at that moment rest entirely with man.

---

Harming others for self-gain,
greed, deceit, and cheating—when will it end?
Harming the many to build a household,
still boasting of wealth and honor before others.
Dark records of yin deeds—
who will take your place when death comes?
The Dao of heaven is impartial—
retribution is clear, each in its time.

---

Is heaven far?
The deluded world seeks it in vain.
Is hell not near?
Countless beings crowd its gates.
Wise and discerning noble ones—
fortunate to be human, diligently set your will.
Will set in a peaceful heart,
even a single good deed, unspoiled, and the Dao is naturally fulfilled.

---

**Three Yang Daoists**

Three Yang Daoists,
sitting opposite cloud peaks, discussing the non-dual.
All dharmas as they are—
all contained in the cold laughter of forgetting the mechanism.

The true nature of ignorance—
this principle is hard to expound, how to realize it?
To realize the primordial origin,
recognize the lone autumn moon in the vast sky.

*Autumn Yang Daoist Friend Visited*
Golden waves and jade nectar—
apart from Guī River, nowhere to seek.
Jade nectar and golden waves,
a single draught harmonizes the five qi.
The great elixir of returning cinnabar,
consumed, brings everlasting joy.
The great elixir of returning cinnabar—
the fortune-thin multitude finds it hard to behold.

*A Daoist Presents Du Fu’s "Spring Excursion" Poetry Scroll*
Excursions in spring, drinking to delight—
all things flourish, flowers like brocade.
Drinking to delight in spring excursions—
how many have ever been led astray?
Confucian scholars and Daoist priests—
how many grasp the will beyond heaven?
Daoist priests and Confucian scholars—
who would renounce worldly passions and rest at once?

*Addressing the Assembly*
Deep in years of Dao cultivation,
though not yet spiritually attuned, the qi and spirit are fine.
Deep in years of Dao cultivation,
amid a thousand scenes, nothing invades.
Fellow practitioners, heed this advice:
fleeting profit and hollow fame—keep them far.
Heed this advice, fellow practitioners—
lay down all entanglements and swiftly cultivate.

*Again*
When body and mind are torn asunder,
this is the true visage of the primordial origin.
Torn asunder, body and mind—
a will like a mountain, transcending past and present.
If you awaken to this trifling truth,
you escape the ceaseless coming and going.
If you awaken to this trifling truth—
in ten thousand kalpas, such an encounter is rare.

*Again*
Dwelling in the world, mingling with the dust—
who understands wordless intoxication?
Mingling with the world, dwelling in the dust—
content in poverty, carefree and untrammeled.
The numinous source never dimmed—
surpassing boundless treasures, the true jewel is possessed.
Never dimmed, the numinous source—
a single qi refined, one ascends to heaven.

*Presented to Lady Dragon-Tiger*
Dim and silent—
who can fathom worldly wisdom and cleverness?
Silent and dim—
desireless, one opens the gates to all wonders.
Embracing simplicity, preserving authenticity—
no worries, no thoughts, no contrivance.
Preserving authenticity, embracing simplicity—
entering sagehood, transcending the mundane lies within each person.

*Composed at Western Mountain*
Cultivating the true near the vulgar—
the initial stage is hard, the heart’s terrain must ripen.
Near the vulgar, cultivating the true—
who remains unstained amid the dust?
Amid forests and springs, indulging in delight—
this is cultivating the true, nothing to verify.
Indulging in delight amid forests and springs—
for now, be a carefree immortal on earth.

*Again*
Settling in meditation amidst the village—
hard to escape the trivial grasping of leisure.
Amidst the village, settling in meditation—
Buddhas and patriarchs ever fear falling into entanglement.
Reclining freely in the mountains—
no worries, no thoughts, true bliss.
Freely reclining in the mountains—
a single spark of numinous light, nothing invades.

*Presented to the Myriad Lotuses Assembly of Yanjing*
Turning the head, reflecting inward—
worldly affairs are endless, worthy of a wry smile.
Reflecting inward, turning the head—
content, return—this is the time to rest.
Rest, rest—awaken!
Do not let greed and delusion gallop like wild horses.
Awaken, rest, rest—
let the years pass, spring after autumn.

*Huairen County*
Embracing benevolence, upholding righteousness—
the Five Emperors and Three Sovereigns governed thus.
Upholding righteousness, embracing benevolence—
all living beings under heaven are of one family.
Diligently studying virtue and the Dao—
establishing the state and founding the family as a model.
Studying virtue and the Dao diligently—
further, let it guide the cultivation of the self.

Painter of the Clear River—
in Chushun, the heart’s resolve is worthy of inspiration.
Painter of the Clear River—
when you arrive early, what is your intent?
Ancestors of the Quanzhen lineage—
painted upon white clouds, transmitted through the ages.
Lineage ancestors of Quanzhen—
eternally guarding Yanshan, renewed day by day.

*Awakening from the Southern Branch (Four Poems)*
*Admonishing the World*

Seeking immortality through false pretenses,
Deluded in truth, chasing the Buddha-mind.
Burning incense, bowing in vain pursuit—
Unsevered ignorance roots deeper karma.

Bitter words are like good medicine,
Loyal advice shines like fine gold.

and ten thousand calamities cannot invade.

Again:
At birth, ignorance weighs heavy;

and the wise shall be your kin.

Beyond the world, truly at ease,
composing verses in untrammeled clarity.

Again:
Do not deceive others gravely,
lest karmic retribution run deep.

warding off encroaching disasters.

exhorting the cultivation of an auspicious, virtuous mind.
On the path of longevity, heed the immortals’ song—

steadily ascending the jadelike peaks.

Again:
Seek not the faults of others,
but reflect on your own strengths.
In conduct, be yielding; in nature, harmonious and radiant.
With no selfishness toward things,
the heart-ground attains cool clarity.

and the incense of wisdom naturally arises.

In effortless ease,
everywhere is the land of immortals.

---

**Self-Reflection**

Paltry profit, hollow fame—
Who can renounce them?
Ahead, the path is perilous, yet still they cling in greed.
Only I dare not indulge in vanity,
For my heart holds a vow to transcend the Three Realms.
Widely spreading a breeze of compassion,
Never slackening in effort.
With a mind embracing forbearance, ever patient,
Opening the heart’s ground like empty space,
Clearly perceiving that which is truly indestructible.

---

**Again**

Hidden high immortals,
Openly bestow protection.
White clouds’ immortal traces shall be fulfilled.
Our lineage’s Seven Ancestors guard Mount Yan,
A myriad golden lotuses, fragrant and resplendent.
Let the assembly settle their minds,
That Daoists may endure long.
Together cultivating pure virtue beyond the stars,
When merit is complete in years to come, we shall ascend to audience with the Origin—
The late Master will surely grant the wine of immortality.

Within stillness, clamor; amid clamor, stillness—
Who discerns the wondrous workings of the numinous source?
Two inverted states merge into emptiness,
Naturally revealing the true message.

Qi traverses the Three Passes,
Spirit roams the Eight Extremities.
Ceaseless, traceless, it comes and goes—
Now cease seeking, abandon inquiry,
And all doubt shall vanish on the path ahead.

In praise of the Master’s immortal form, imperishable:
Jade bones, pristine in origin,
Golden elixir already perfected.
Eternal spring, ageless—what year could bring decay?
A single nature, rounded and complete, pervades the Ganges’ sands,
Yet the discarded husk remains whole, unchanged.

Rare across ten thousand generations,
Scarce in any age—
Disciples from the ends of heaven gather in haste.
Dwelling in peace, they venerate the true countenance,
Burning incense for a hundred thousand spans, three days unbroken.

*Six Poems in Crimson Dots*
Composed five days after the Double Ninth

The body enters emptiness,
Yet this alone cannot serve as proof.
On the path of true emptiness,
Qi and spirit converge—
The yang spirit emerges.

Should you meet a kindred soul,
This matter may be entrusted.
Hearken well, cast doubt aside:
When cultivation is complete, heaven itself shall guard you.

Again—

I hear of cultivation’s ways,
A thousand differences, ten thousand divergences—hard to rely upon.
On the path of true emptiness,
Who attains the essence?
Only one who lets go may return.

Deeds accumulate boundlessly,
Merit must reach three thousand.
With awakened heart,
Stroll freely on cloud-steps,
Ascending beyond celestial immortals.

Again—

Seeking the Dao, pursuing truth,
Calm the mind, endure the search for the right path.
The handle of the elixir knife—
Hosts of immortals rejoice,
A single luminous pearl gleams.

Illuminating the primordial origin,
Recognizing head and shadow as one—
Divine and sagely,
Within, pure joy abounds,
Beyond the world, idly chanting.

Again—

Cultivation is hard to achieve,
Ignorance stirs flames everywhere.
Summoning calamity,
Time slips by in vain—
How escape birth and death?

Awaken early to past transgressions,
No longer cling to self and others.
Return to truth,
Ever clearly discerning,
Set to work and reap the immortal fruit.

Again—

Radiant Double Yang,
Crisp autumn air stirs pure delight.
Singing immortal songs,
Yellow blossoms match the season,
Each petal reflecting true nature.

Small balustrades fragrant,
The assembly seated in reverence.
Truly serene,
Pure wind, untainted—
Ten thousand households, a thousand gates rejoice.

*Roaming Fiveflower Mountain in Late Spring, Following the Master’s Rhyme*

Yesterday’s spring outing,
Our company seemed to ride phoenix and simurgh.
Kindred spirits together,
Hearts at ease, we ventured forth,
Straight into the Peach Blossom Grotto.

By the clear stream,
Idly listening to the zither’s three refrains.
True joy stirs,
Freely welcomed and sent off—
What care for Zhuang Zhou’s dream?

*Divination Song*
At Jade Void Abbey’s night scene, the Master ordered all to hasten—
*Divination Song* was renamed *Northern Bliss*.

True nature, do not wander in vain,
The two substances ever guard each other.
Who knows this message?
It is having within nothing.

The jeweled tripod’s blossoms unfurl,
Jade doors radiate golden light.
Become one who has crossed to the cool other shore—
The work of purity is complete.

*Three Poems for the Sagely Dynasty*
After the Yizhou Ritual, Guo Zhiquan was commanded to expound two chapters on the Dao and virtue

Ancient bonds run deep,
Good roots planted firmly,
The steadfast heart of the aspirant.
Moved by our gate’s vast teaching,
Broadly opening the way—
Together we discourse on merit’s fulfillment.

Sleepless through the night,
Cloud-borne companions in lofty assembly,
Penetrating the profoundest mystery.
Within the five thousand characters,
Forget the fish-trap and grasp the fish—
Behold the immortal within yourself.

Deep in the quiet night, I don robes and sit at ease,
Listening to the stringless zither.
Ceasing lofty discourse, subtle words silently penetrate the mystery—
Freely abiding in the turtle’s unbroken breath.
Yin and yang rise and fall,
The four greats harmonize in balance,
Bones strong, spirit whole.
Embracing the primal origin, a single point completes the practice—
Behold the dancing immortal embryo.

*Mid-Autumn Moon Viewing at Taiping Xingguo Abbey*
The sea is calm, the mountains still,
Autumn’s pure light fills all,
A cool night gathers kindred souls.
We open our hearts,
Delighting past the third watch,
Further discoursing on the profound.
Perfect clarity dawns in sudden awakening,
Selfless and universally illuminating,
Virtuous deeds fully encompassed.
This very night, perceiving thoroughly, all natures interpenetrate—
Attaining the immortality of the solid earth.

*Ten Lyrics to "Yi Jian Mei"*
Following the rhyme of Master Yilaci Zhongze, composed at Yonghe Hermitage in Yizhou.

Only when the ninth nine-day period ends does the sun warm.
Spring harmonizes with lofty virtue,
Dreamless, the heavens stretch long.
Roaming freely through the ten directions and three realms,
Summer’s heat still met,
Unheeding autumn’s frost.

Awakened to true leisure, all affairs forgotten,
Naturally at ease and joyful,
The mind-ground cool and clear.
The original single point expands boundlessly,
Dispersing all demons,
Alone manifesting majestic radiance.

*Addressing the Assembly, Reusing the Previous Rhyme*
Externally accumulating hidden merit, internally fortifying yang.
The everlasting spring addresses the assembly—
These words are especially long.
If one can suddenly awaken to non-doing,
Past karma dissolves like frost beneath the blazing sun.

No need to still the mind or forget the six desires.
When merit is complete and conduct fulfilled,
Transcending heat and cold.
Carefree and unconstrained, drifting east or west,
Thoroughly awakened to the human realm—
Thus concealing one’s brilliance.

*Addressing the Assembly at Taiping Xingguo Abbey*
Heaven bestows Pingyao as a fine place to rest the heart.
Jade halls lie hushed,
Ancient cypresses stand dense.
Cool shade tightly seals the grotto-heaven’s seclusion,
Villages nearby,
Yet quieter than mountain forests.

Who can seek the Way of purity and non-doing?
At Taiping Xingguo Abbey,
Find a true kindred spirit.
I urge you to swiftly awaken—do not delay.
Accept it in this very moment,
And the worthy and sagely will descend upon you.

*Sent to Daoist Friends in Weizhou*
Beyond the waters beside the immortal’s pot,
By the Western River we bade farewell,
Sincerity and depth unforgettable.
Unable to speak at leisure before setting out,
Crossing the ridge through bitter cold,
My coming intent hasty.

Fortunately, peace reaches the land of the Dao,
Hunyuan abounds in sufficiency,
All affairs at peace.
If someone travels east, send them new verses,
To report to kindred spirits
And reveal my conduct and whereabouts.

*Ode to the Front High Mountain*
Newly acquired, the front high mountain stands in a cluster.
A realm of pure emptiness,
An ancient immortal altar.
Heaven pities my arduous toil,
Granting me advanced years,
Teaching me to open my countenance.

Silently I thank the lofty vault for bestowing leisure.
Amid pines and upon rocks,
All pursuit is severed.
Joyfully content, delight knows no bounds—
Worthy to behold whether walking or sitting.

*Again*
Newly acquired, the front high mountain proclaims itself.
A realm of pure emptiness,
An ancient immortal altar.

Peaks rise sheer and towering,
Pines and cypresses stand in rows.
The Daoist’s plan to retreat from the red dust—
In the azure grotto, high and serene,
No affairs to bind the heart.

White hair hangs heavy, frost at both temples.
Within the shadow of green pines,
All adornment fades to remoteness.
Coming and going in playful ease as the sun slants low—
Walking brings coolness,
Sitting brings coolness.

*Again*
Who can know the newly gained Front High?
Its purity surpasses the world,
Yet the poet’s brush cannot capture it.
From the Peak of Morning Ascent, I gaze in idle leisure—
Before reaching Penglai,
I first arrive at Jasper Pool.

A gust of pine wind blows into my ears,
Celestial strains drift faintly,
Penetrating the subtle and profound.
When the mood strikes, I lean on my staff and wander the clouded stream—
Walking is fitting,
Sitting is fitting.

*Expressing My Feelings to Master Cheng*
My Dao studies bear no fruit, yet Heaven is not stingy.
I occupy an undeserved reputation,
Hard-pressed to claim true attainment.
From now on, my resolve redoubles—
Gazing east, I let all rest,
Never descending from the western mountain.

Deep gratitude to my steadfast friends,
Whose support in all four seasons never fails,
Providing me with clothing and food.
At times of celebration, ascending to Morning Ascent Peak,
Both merit and conduct perfected,
Daily attending a thousand altars.

*Expressing My Feelings to Master Liu*
A single spark of numinous clarity, originally still,
Flowing with whatever arises, responding to all conditions.
Recognizing all these as they are—
In motion, it is round;
In stillness, it is round.

In daily use, it is selfless and untouched by edges,
The subtle workings of pure emptiness—
This Dharma is worthy of transmission.
Guiding others to sudden awakening into non-action—
Walking, words forgotten;
Sitting, words forgotten.

*Descending the Mountain*
For love of Front High, I realize my excess.

Heaven-born barriers block the flow of harmonious qi.
Where lies the path ahead to seek the Dao’s affinity?
Without the fortune for leisure,
With the fate for toil—
Even in old age, merit remains incomplete, left to the whims of demons.

The Long Spring Teachings warn:
Beware of wasted time.
Those who from the start attain the Dao and study immortality—
Their merit is not great,
Their conduct is not great.

Too late to begin—

*Exhorting the Assembly After the Yizhou Ritual*
How can the myriad conditions ever cease?
When will the thousand cares ever quiet?
When emotions fade, all conditions suddenly end;
When thoughts vanish, all cares wholly cease.

Ask yourself: how much time remains?
Yet still you toy with worldly cleverness.
If you knew to turn your light inward now,
You would not wait in sorrow as misfortune nears.

*Zhaojun’s Resentment*
*Inscribed on the Eastern Wall of Dongzhi Abbey, Quanzhou*

On the Double Ninth, a leisurely stroll,
I arrive at Wuqing’s southern crossing.
Gazing afar at the auspicious scene—
Waters stretch boundless.

For days, overcast skies and gentle rain,
Now deep among the reeds.
Reveling amid the shifting waters and clouds,
I look toward West Mountain.

*Phoenix Perches on the Wutong Tree*
*Observing the World*

The Great Teaching spreads throughout the world,
Returning to simplicity, preserving the True—
In daily practice, offering expedient means.
Expedient true compassion, pure and still in vow,
The heart connects, gradually sensing worldly ties grow distant.

The superior person, wise and enlightened, is easily persuaded.
Having awakened to the mysterious wind,
Swiftly forget knowledge and perception.
How can worldly affairs be long cherished?
Better to recognize and verify the original face.

*Concluding the Lower Scroll of Preserving the Light*

chunks.original_text: 葆光集 经名：葆光集。 元尹志平撰。 三卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》太平部。 葆光集序 伏以浑沦未判，已含天地之真； 清浊将分，遂运阴阳之妙。 由是三才既立，万化俱成，品物咸亨，异人间出。 如真人者，姓尹氏，世族沧洲人也。 祖先一母，三产九男，中内七人，各封八县。 厥后簪缨炽盛，抑今碑铭昭然。 至真人愈为盛事。 童年入定，看乾坤造化之原； 丱岁出家，了性命超升之诀。 接人救物，考古规今，穷万事之始终，列千贤之先后。 博施广化，泛爱宽容，为而不争，犯而不校。 欲仁而斯仁至矣，不善者亦善覆之。 盖由达向背之情，晓幽明之故，既已往而弗谏，但将来者可追。 知进退存亡，恕大小多少，流言不入，任毁誉以何移； 凡事饱谙，信浮沉而所适。 随流若类，混迹同尘，受垢安身，托词警世。 清吟编简，意传万古以无遗； 法语敷扬，志取一时之有补。 可以继全真而演教，叙正派以流芳，开众妙之玄门，指三清之直路。 高县慧日，照破邪阴，大振宗风，荡除凶秽。 故使门庭洒落，境界清凉，屏幽夜之迷途，附长春之胜域。 拟开灵沼，植万朵之金莲； 空驾神舟，载一轮之皓月。 是知人难调制，道不加行，可怀宝而坐忘，或写忧而游戏。 不离方寸，历遍遐荒，复挈大千，纳于毫末。 心田晃朗，照知闻见觉之前； 性海渊澄，湛成住坏空之后。 感而即应，舍之则藏，淡泊于无生，逍遥于寂灭。 如如不动，冥超劫外之天； 了了常存，永在现前之地。 般般勘破，处处圆成，信手拈来，转头放下。 诸门遍晓，悟万法以归心； 多劫曾修，证一真而合道。 是以曩离尘世，久处仙乡，优游于碧落之中，冥赏于清都之内。 上方克约，等师父之千年； 下会来期，诞自身于次日。 是谓至礼无体，至让无辞，按美名无称之称，合上古不德之德。 其缘有庆，其故无私。 盖怀弘道之微机，以示化人之雅范斗不亏细行，终累大功，既足清标，敢无美誉。 浪裁狂语，冒赞幽情，不防条罪之三千，私发师真之万亡石耳。 夫《葆光集》者，即真人之所作也。 自承教一十三年，常坐于大长春宫宝玄堂之重室葆光之轩，日有在京士大夫，及远方尊宿，参问请益，求索唱和。 或自述怀遣兴，警诫劝示。 复因诸方游历，经临景物，题跋赞咏。 所得诗词歌颂，编列次第，分为三卷，以轩名而立号焉。 或谓葆者蔽也，谓蔽藏灵识，不令外驰，虽应万变，不失虚寂之体。 又光者照也，谓照破昏暗，坦然前进，不致陷坠，径入希夷之域。 又集者聚也，谓聚积珠玉众宝等类，施设运用，以济贫苦之者。 述作之义，大略然否。 或谓诗有四炼，炼字不如炼句，炼句不如炼格，炼格不如炼意。 意者志之用，诗思之委也。 故在心为志，发言成诗。 诗之成也，不必字精句健。 风骚属时之为美，美者美于德，尚于志也。 志者禀於道，感而动之，托于辞； 和而节之，成于文。 文者奋于言，言者无罪，则思无邪也。 夫正情性，明得失，主忠信，戒权谋，止强梁，守柔弱，宝慈俭，去奢泰，崇高节，美教化，真人之诗为深得之。 如云：心中实行真为宝，口内虚词未足奇。 又云：智源起处奸邪盛，礼貌彰时道德衰。 又云：性暴每闻人化虎，心慈果见木飞龙。
chunks.translated_text:
**Preface to the *Baoguang Collection***

When the primordial chaos had yet to divide, it already contained the true essence of Heaven and Earth; as clarity and turbidity began to separate, the subtle workings of yin and yang unfolded. Thus, the Three Powers were established, the myriad transformations completed, all things flourished, and extraordinary persons emerged among humankind.

Such was the True Person, surnamed Yin, of the illustrious lineage of Cangzhou. His ancestors, born of a single mother, produced nine sons in three births, seven of whom were enfeoffed across eight counties. Thereafter, their cap and sash flourished in splendor—even now, stele inscriptions attest to their renown. Yet the True Person’s achievements surpassed all.

In childhood, he entered stillness, contemplating the origins of Heaven and Earth’s creation; in youth, he left the household, mastering the secrets of nature, life, and transcendence. He guided others and saved beings, examined the ancients to regulate the present, fathomed the beginnings and ends of all affairs, and ranked the worthies of past and present. His beneficence was vast, his transformations boundless; he embraced all with magnanimity, acted without contention, and though provoked, did not retaliate. Where he desired benevolence, benevolence arose; even the unvirtuous were covered in goodness.

This was because he grasped the sentiments of alignment and opposition, understood the causes of the hidden and manifest, and though the past could not be admonished, the future could yet be pursued. He knew advance and retreat, preservation and loss, and practiced forbearance in matters great and small. Slander did not sway him, nor did praise or blame alter his course. In all things, he was thoroughly versed, trusting in the ebb and flow to guide his path.

He moved with the current, blending his traces with the dust; he endured disgrace to secure his person and employed words to admonish the world. His refined verses, inscribed on bamboo and silk, conveyed meaning to ten thousand ages without omission; his dharma teachings, disseminated far, aimed to benefit the present moment.

He could succeed the Quanzhen in expounding the teachings, chronicle the orthodox lineage to perpetuate its fragrance, open the mysterious gate of all wonders, and point the straight path to the Three Purities. Like the sun of wisdom suspended high, he dispelled the shadows of heresy, greatly revived the ancestral wind, and swept away all malevolence and filth. Thus, his gate and courtyard were pure and bright, his realm cool and serene—banishing the lost paths of dark nights to join the sublime domain of Everlasting Spring.

He planned to open a numinous pond, planting myriad golden lotuses; to empty the spirit-boat, bearing a single wheel of luminous moon. Yet knowing that people are difficult to discipline and the Dao does not force its way, he cherished the treasure within and sat in forgetfulness, or expressed his cares through play. Without leaving the square inch of his heart, he traversed distant wilds, then grasped the great thousandfold world and contained it within a hair’s tip.

His mind-field shone bright, illuminating all before perception, hearing, and awareness; his nature-ocean was deep and limpid, perfectly reflecting the cycles of dwelling, decay, and emptiness. Moved, he responded; set aside, he concealed. He was indifferent to non-arising, carefree in quiescence. Unmoving, he transcended the heavens beyond kalpas; ever-present, he abided in the realm before his eyes. All things he examined and penetrated, everywhere he perfected—effortlessly grasping, instantly releasing.

Master of all gates, he awakened to the myriad dharmas and returned them to the heart; having cultivated across many kalpas, he realized the One Truth and merged with the Dao. Thus, long departed from the dusty world, he dwelled for ages in the immortal realm, roaming freely amid the azure vaults, enjoying the mysteries within the Pure Capital.

Above, he matched the millennial covenant of his master and father; below, he awaited the appointed time, manifesting his own body on the following day. This is called: the highest ritual has no form, the utmost yielding has no words—embracing the unnameable name of beauty, uniting with the ancient virtue that claims no virtue.

His causes were auspicious, his reasons selfless. Holding the subtle mechanism of the great Dao, he displayed the elegant model for transforming others. Though trifling conduct may seem insignificant, it ultimately accumulates into great merit. His purity of bearing was sufficient—how could it lack praise?

These reckless, wild words dare to extol his profound sentiments, unafraid of transgressing the three thousand prohibitions, privately invoking the ten thousand vanished traces of the Master’s truth.

The *Baoguang Collection* is the work of this True Person. For thirteen years after receiving the teachings, he often sat in the inner chamber of the Baoguang Pavilion within the Baoxuan Hall of the Great Everlasting Spring Palace. Daily, scholar-officials from the capital and esteemed elders from afar came to seek his counsel, request instruction, or solicit poetic exchanges. Sometimes he expressed his feelings to dispel ennui or offered admonitions and encouragement. During his travels through various regions, he also composed colophons and eulogies upon encountering scenic sites.

The poems, lyrics, songs, and hymns he gathered were arranged in order and divided into three volumes, named after the pavilion. Some say *bao* means "to conceal," signifying the concealment of numinous awareness to prevent its outward dissipation—though responding to myriad changes, it never loses its empty and tranquil essence. *Guang* means "to illuminate," signifying the piercing of darkness to advance unfettered, avoiding pitfalls to enter the realm of the subtle and formless. *Ji* means "to gather," signifying the accumulation of treasures like pearls and jade, deployed to aid the impoverished and suffering.

Such is the general meaning of this compilation—whether it is apt or not.

Others say poetry has four refinements: refining words is inferior to refining lines, refining lines to refining structure, and refining structure to refining intent. Intent is the function of aspiration, the culmination of poetic thought. Thus, what is in the heart becomes aspiration, and when spoken, becomes poetry. The completion of poetry need not rely on exquisite words or robust lines. The *Feng* and *Sao* were beautiful in their time, but beauty lies in virtue, and virtue exalts aspiration. Aspiration is endowed by the Dao; moved, it stirs and is entrusted to words; harmonized and regulated, it becomes literature. Literature arises from words, and if words are blameless, then thoughts are without deviation.

To rectify emotions and nature, clarify gains and losses, uphold loyalty and trust, reject cunning schemes, cease aggression, embrace softness and weakness, treasure compassion and frugality, abandon extravagance and excess, revere lofty integrity, and beautify education—these are the profound attainments of the True Person’s poetry.

As he said:
*"True treasure lies in the heart’s sincere conduct;
Empty words from the mouth are hardly marvelous."*

And again:
*"Where the source of wisdom arises, treachery and deceit flourish;
When courtesy and decorum are manifest, the Dao and virtue decline."*

And again:
*"A violent nature often hears of men transformed into tigers;
A compassionate heart indeed sees trees where dragons take flight."*

chunks.original_text: 又云：从他外境魔千遍，一片真心不解惊。 又云：宠辱不惊君子性，是非宁动法王身。 凡此类例，篇篇皆然，幸览者知之耳。 若懈慢而不览，鲁莽而不知，呜呼哀哉。 唯沁州长官杜德康，为当世贤者也。 一见此集，普愿众闻，遂募工镂板，以广其传。 庶使英明之士、同器之流，览其文而知其实，悟其理而得其趣。 豁然颖脱尘累，高蹈真空，名列丹台，永超生灭，真谓仁人之用心也哉。 时岁在己亥重九日，门弟子烟霞逸人，三肃熏沐拜书。 葆光集上 清和真人尹志平撰
chunks.translated_text:
And again:
*"Though outer demons assail a thousand times,
A single true heart knows no fear."*

And again:
*"The noble nature remains unshaken by favor or disgrace;
The Dharma King’s body stirs not amid right or wrong."*

Such examples abound throughout these writings—may the reader take heed. For those who grow lax and neglect to read, or act rashly without understanding, alas! What sorrow.

Only Du Dekang, Magistrate of Qinzhou, was a worthy of this age. Upon seeing this collection, he wished all to hear its message, and thus commissioned artisans to carve woodblocks, that its transmission might spread. May enlightened scholars and those of kindred spirit read these words and grasp their truth, awaken to their principles and find their essence. Then, breaking free from worldly entanglements, they may ascend to the true emptiness, their names inscribed on the cinnabar terrace, forever transcending birth and death—truly the intent of a benevolent heart.

Written on the Double Ninth of the year *jihai*, by the disciple the Mist-and-Cloud Recluse, with threefold reverence and ablutions.

*Baoguang Collection*, compiled by the Pure Harmony True Person Yin Zhiping.

chunks.original_text: 七言绝句 金山 自宣德州至田相公营，约七八千里，乃金山之北也。 西北行程近八千，却成南下过金山。 金山更向西南望，才见阴山缥缈间。 又 曾从神仙日下游，五千里外水分头。 时人只解东溟注，不见长河西北流。 又 西出阴山万里多，一重山外一重河。 大河五次亲曾渡，余外山河未见他。 过大石林牙契丹国 大石是契丹语，学士名，林牙是小名。 中原呼大石林牙为国号。 辽因金破失家乡，西走番戎万里疆。 十载经营无定止，却来此地务农桑。 又 群雄战力得农桑，大石林牙号国王。 几帝聚兵成百万，到今衰落亦城荒。 西域物熟，节气比中原较早，故记之。 止渴黄梅已得尝，充饥素椹又持将。 时当小满才初夏，椹熟梅黄麦亦黄。 师适有他往，而云水高人踵门者日无一二，因作此。 师去交朋来往稀，知心还似不相知。 胸中有志忘人事，与我真情正所宜。 唯太守家李提控日逐一过 此道难行步步高，时人见者谩徒劳。 陇西道友知何意，忙裹偷闲日一遭。 自咏 世念如今已不生，惟思道德未精诚。 蒙师训教经千百，是处无过苦己行。 段公觅得小鱼放生 乞得纤鳞兔受烹，放归溪水任游行。 莫言他日成鲸去，目下从容也畅情。 宝玄堂作 出门开眼见西山，只为缘轻未得还。 身在葆光虽散诞，此心常忆白云间。 和陈学士 西山终日有云烟，只为人心未了然。 谁肯回头林下问，本来面目是真仙。 和赵讲师 休向心田挂一毫，嘱君四句记来牢。 众中不见他人过，便许先生道德高。 刘宣差病索诗 欲求轻健得安然，试伴长春向宝玄。 百日消疏如肯受，他年骨壮自神全， 蒙师旨去山东，别燕京，偶得－绝 西域归来万里余，区区尚未得幽居。 他时若到安闲处，静掩柴扉不出庐。 和王道录 物物知空任去来，头头心上觉花开。 是非过耳休重问，道德终身莫下怀。 又 教风普振遇长春，岂择官寮与士民。 个个携将归紫府，人人点化出红尘。 真人有天上人间，四绝依韵奉和 天上真仙无事忙，人间愚昧自相妨。 不知心是根源主，终日空劳礼十方。 又 天上群仙心本同，人间万法总虚空。 不知道德浑沦妙，犹自谈西与说东。 又 天上庄严道力成，人间法像善经营。 不知上圣垂方便，执性昏昧几个明。 又 天上真功达者稀，人间立像要归依。 若人顿悟无生理，便是吾门最上机。 燕京会首问作福 作福须从损己求，修真只要肯心休。 古今贤达无多事，福慧双全第一流。 自咏 自顾微躯劣弱多，寻常五脏却安和。 虽然未达青霄去，幸免今生苦战魔。 又 人羡刚强是俊英，我怜柔弱得全生。 试观举世贪名者，尽在尘中苦战争。 又 受教师真三十年，几回责我不周全。 暗中速改即成老，死上头来尚未圆。 宝玄堂下得房二间 两间静室一间空，片席安眠乐在中。 莫怪忘贫随分过，都缘造道未精通。 又 暖室明窗我则眠，返思天下有余寒。 三冬谁得优游过，多被刀兵岁岁残。 又 静室安居明更清，等闲不惹世间情。 从他外景魔千遍，一片真心不解惊。 又 本来一点最孤灵，染着人情万事生。 欲要归根清净去，应须返朴入圆成。 又 用时行道学长春，舍则潜心默契真。 一性既通非内外，两般消息没疏亲。 又 苦思奇句竟何争，无碍狂吟信笔成。 乐性发言聊畅道，兴来自得不求名。
chunks.translated_text:
**Seven-Character Quatrains**

**Golden Mountain**
From Xuande Prefecture to Lord Tian’s Camp—
some seven or eight thousand *li*—lies north of Golden Mountain.
Northwest the journey nears eight thousand,
yet southward we pass Golden Mountain.
Gazing southwest from Golden Mountain,
only then do the Yin Mountains shimmer faintly in the distance.

**Another**
Once I wandered beneath the immortals’ sun,
five thousand *li* beyond, the waters part their ways.
Men know only the eastern sea’s embrace,
blind to the Great River’s northwest flow.

**Another**
West beyond the Yin Mountains, ten thousand *li* and more,
range upon range of mountains, river upon river.
Five times I crossed the Great River,
yet countless peaks and streams remain unseen.

**Passing the Great Stone Linya of the Qidan State**
"Great Stone" is the Qidan word for "scholar"; "Linya" is a lesser name.
The Central Plains call the Great Stone Linya a state title.
When Liao fell to Jin and lost its homeland,
they fled west to the barbarian lands, ten thousand *li* away.
For a decade they wandered, rootless,
until settling here to till the soil.

**Another**
Through force of arms, the multitudes secured their fields,
and the Great Stone Linya was hailed as king.
Though emperors amassed armies of millions,
now all lies in decline, the cities desolate.

**The Western Regions’ early seasons**—noted for their advance over the Central Plains.
To slake thirst, yellow plums are already tasted;
to sate hunger, white mulberries are gathered.
At the season of Lesser Fullness, early summer’s dawn,
mulberries ripen, plums yellow, wheat turns gold.

**The Master departs on other business**, and cloud-wandering adepts now seldom darken his door. Thus this verse.
The Master gone, friends and companions grow few;
even kindred spirits seem strangers now.
With lofty aims, he forgets worldly affairs—
just as true feeling should be with me.

**Only Prefect Li of the Household daily visits**
This path is hard, each step ascending higher;
those who see it dismiss it as vain toil.
What does my friend from Longxi intend?
Stealing moments from his busyness, he comes once a day.

**Self-Reflection**
Worldly cares no longer stir in me,
yet my thoughts on the Dao and virtue lack sincerity.
Though I’ve received the Master’s teachings a thousandfold,
in every place, I err only in failing to discipline myself.

**Lord Duan retrieves a small fish for release**
A slender scale begged for, spared the pot,
returned to the stream to roam at will.
Say not that one day it may grow into a whale—
even now, its leisure brings joy.

**Composed at Baoxuan Hall**
Stepping out, the eye meets the Western Mountains,
yet for my light karmic ties, I cannot return.
Though my body lingers in Baoguang, carefree and unrestrained,
my heart ever dwells amid the white clouds.

**Matching Academician Chen’s Verse**
The Western Mountains, daylong veiled in mist,
exist because men’s hearts remain unenlightened.
Who would turn back to ask the woods below?
The original face is the true immortal.

**Matching Instructor Zhao’s Verse**
Do not cling even to a hair’s weight in the field of the heart.
I charge you: remember these four lines well.
Seeing no faults in others,
one may be called a master of high virtue.

**For Officer Liu Xuanchai, ill and seeking a poem**
To seek lightness and health, find peace,
try keeping company with Perpetual Spring in Baoxuan.
If you accept a hundred days of abstinence,
in years to come, your bones will be strong, your spirit whole.

**On receiving the Master’s command to depart for Shandong, bidding farewell to Yanjing—an impromptu quatrain**
Returning from the Western Regions, ten thousand *li* and more,
yet still I’ve found no quiet abode.
When at last I reach a place of ease,
I’ll shut my wicker gate and never leave my hut.

**Matching Daoist Recorder Wang’s Verse**
All things know emptiness, coming and going as they will;
in every thought, the heart’s flowers bloom.
Let right and wrong pass the ear—ask no more;
never let the Dao and virtue slip from mind.

**Another**
The teaching wind spreads, meeting Perpetual Spring,
indiscriminate toward officials or common folk.
Each is led to the Purple Palace,
everyone transformed, rising from the red dust.

**The True Person’s "Heaven and Earth"**—four quatrains matched in rhyme

**I**
Heaven’s true immortals, idle yet never idle;
earth’s fools, self-impeding in their folly.
Unknowing that the heart is the root and master,
they labor in vain, bowing to the ten directions.

**II**
Heaven’s host of immortals share one heart;
earth’s myriad dharmas are all empty.
Not knowing the wondrous oneness of Dao and virtue,
they still prattle of west and east.

**III**
Heaven’s splendor arises from the power of the Dao;
earth’s forms are shaped by good deeds.
Unknowing the sagely ones’ expedient means,
they cling to delusion, how few see clearly!

**IV**
Heaven’s true merit is grasped by few;
earth’s images demand refuge.
If one suddenly awakens to the principle of non-birth,
this is the highest mechanism of our gate.

**To the Leaders of Yanjing on Performing Merit**
Merit must be sought through self-denial;
cultivating truth requires a willing heart at rest.
The wise of past and present had few affairs—
those perfect in both merit and wisdom stand first.

**Self-Reflection**
Gazing at this frail, weak body,
my five organs remain at peace.
Though I’ve not yet ascended to the azure skies,
I’m spared this life’s bitter demonic wars.

**Another**
Men admire the strong as heroes,
but I pity the weak who preserve their lives.
Look at all the world’s fame-seekers—
mired in dust, they wage endless war.

**Another**
Thirty years under the true Master’s teaching,
how often he reproached my imperfections!
Swiftly mending my ways in secret, I near old age,
yet on the brink of death, I’m still not whole.

**Two rooms obtained beneath Baoxuan Hall**
Two quiet chambers, one left empty,
a single mat for sleep—joy lies within.
Blame me not for forgetting poverty, living as I please;
it’s only that my mastery of the Dao remains imperfect.

**Another**
A warm room, bright windows—here I sleep,
yet I recall the world’s lingering cold.
Who passes the three winters in ease?
Most fall to the sword, year after year.

**Another**
Dwelling in quiet chambers, clarity grows clearer;
casually, I avoid worldly entanglements.
Though outer demons assail a thousandfold,
my single true heart knows no fear.

**Another**
Originally, a single spark, most solitary and numinous,
tainted by human feelings, ten thousand affairs arise.
To return to the root, to purity,
one must revert to simplicity, enter perfect completion.

**Another**
When active, practice the Dao, study Perpetual Spring;
when at rest, silently merge with the true.
Once the single nature is penetrated, there is no inside or out;
both states flow without near or far.

**Another**
Why strive for clever lines? What is there to vie for?
Unfettered, I chant wildly, writing as the brush moves.
Delighting in my nature, I speak to gladden the Dao;
inspired, I find contentment, seeking no fame.

**For Lord Duan, who retrieved a small fish for release** (repeated for context)
A slender scale begged for, spared the pot,
returned to the stream to roam at will.
Say not that one day it may grow into a whale—
even now, its leisure brings joy.
